chapter.para: The core functionality of &productname; is provided by &kube;. Use the kubectl command to communicate with &kube;. &kube; requires a valid authentication. Each authenticated user then has a set of privileges assigned.

sect1.title: Gaining Cluster Access
sect1.para: This section is intended for normal users. If you are the admin, refer to .
To access the &kube; cluster, execute the following steps:

step.para: Get your credentials consisting of an e-mail address and a password from your cluster administrator. You also need the FQDN to the admin node.
Download the kubeconfig by visiting https://ADMIN_NODE/kubecofnig. Log in with your credentials and store the kubeconfig as ~/.kube/config.

sect1.title: Using kubectl
sect1.para: kubectl is a command line user interface to the &kube; cluster. By default, the authorization credentials are read from the file ~/.kube/config.
To perform a specific command, at least one of your assigned roles needs to have the required privilege. The default syntax for kubectl commands is:

listitem.para: The operation that is performed on the resource, for example create, get, or delete.
The resource type on which the operation is performed, for example pod, service, or namespace.
The name of specific resources (TYPE). If omitted, the command is performed on all resources of a type.
This allows setting further details for the command, for example the &kube; API server URL.
